Key Findings

  • The total spend analysed by AI DOGE is £146.5M across 16,065 transactions.
  • The data coverage spans 4 financial years, from 2021/22 to 2024/25.
  • The spending data is sourced from South Ribble Borough Council's published spending records, in accordance with the Local Government Transparency Code.
  • The analysis found no issues with duplicates, split payments, round-number anomalies, and Benford's Law results.
  • The data consists of 16,065 transactions, providing a comprehensive overview of the council's spending habits.

Introduction to South Ribble's Spending

South Ribble Borough Council, a district council in Lancashire, England, has published its spending records for the past 4 financial years. The data, which covers the period from 2021/22 to 2024/25, provides valuable insights into the council's spending habits. With a total spend of £146.5M across 16,065 transactions, the data offers a comprehensive overview of the council's financial activities.

The analysis of the spending data found no issues with duplicates, split payments, round-number anomalies, and Benford's Law results. This suggests that the council's financial transactions are transparent and follow standard accounting practices. However, it is essential to continue monitoring the council's spending to ensure that it remains accountable to its citizens.

The spending data is sourced from the council's published spending records, which are made available under the Local Government Transparency Code. This code requires local authorities to publish their spending data regularly, promoting transparency and accountability in public spending.

Analysis of the Spending Data

The analysis of the spending data reveals that the council has made a total of 16,065 transactions over the 4-year period. This averages out to approximately 4,016 transactions per year, indicating a significant volume of financial activity. The total spend of £146.5M is substantial, and it is essential to examine the data closely to understand the council's spending patterns.

Although the data does not provide information on specific suppliers, it is crucial to analyse the spending patterns to identify areas where the council can improve its financial management. By examining the data, citizens and stakeholders can gain a better understanding of how the council allocates its resources and make informed decisions about its spending.

Conclusion and Next Steps

The analysis of South Ribble Borough Council's spending data provides valuable insights into the council's financial activities. Although the data does not reveal any issues with duplicates, split payments, round-number anomalies, and Benford's Law results, it is essential to continue monitoring the council's spending to ensure that it remains accountable to its citizens.

Citizens and stakeholders can play an active role in promoting transparency and accountability in public spending by examining the spending data and providing feedback to the council. By working together, we can ensure that the council's spending is efficient, effective, and accountable to the public.

What You Can Do

  • Submit a Freedom of Information request to South Ribble Borough Council about their spending patterns and financial management practices.
  • Attend council committee meetings, which are open to the public, to gain a better understanding of the council's decision-making processes.
  • Check the council's published contracts register to examine the details of their contracts and agreements with suppliers.
  • Write to your local councillor about your concerns regarding the council's spending and financial management practices.
  • Visit aidoge.co.uk to explore the full spending data and gain a deeper understanding of the council's financial activities.
This article is based on South Ribble Borough Council's published spending data covering 2021/22 to 2024/25. All figures are drawn directly from transactions published under the Local Government Transparency Code. Analysis by AI DOGE.
